subject: Art & Design
title: Dark Patterns: Design That Deceives
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Dark Patterns: Design That Deceives.

hook.text: 'Unsubscribe' is in tiny gray text at the bottom. 'Stay subscribed!' is a giant green button. That's a dark pattern.

buildup.text: Dark patterns are deceptive UI techniques that trick users into actions they didn't intend: buying, subscribing.

discovery.text: Common types: confirm-shaming ('No, I don't want to save money'), hidden costs, trick questions, roach motels (easy in.

twist.text: The EU's GDPR and California's CCPA now legally prohibit some dark patterns. Regulation is catching up.

climax.text: Amazon's cancellation flow once required 6 clicks and 4 pages. Public backlash and regulators forced simplification.

punchline.text: Dark patterns win clicks. They lose trust. Trust is harder to rebuild.

quiz.question: What is a 'roach motel' dark pattern?
options: Easy to sign up but extremely difficult to cancel or leave
A design that attracts users with fake discounts
A pop-up that appears repeatedly until clicked
